revised_title: Inhibition and Excitation in Reciprocal Innervation of Antagonistic Muscles
tldr: The author examines the reciprocal innervation of antagonistic muscles through the "direct-flexion reflex" in the dog's hind limb. They found that the skin-field and afferent nerve-trunks responsible for eliciting inhibition and excitation are the same. The study also highlights the differences in latency and summation of stimuli for the reflex inhibition and contraction. This research contributes to the understanding of the normal reflex process and the role of inhibition in muscle physiology.
